dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A two hundred thousand dollar average coverage for millennials, but they actually need around five hundred thousand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A two hundred thousand dollar average coverage for millennials, but they actually need around five hundred thousand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials with life insurance have an average of $100,000 in life insurance protection in place, enough to cover one fifth (22%) of their self-reported coverage needs of $452,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a three hundred thousand dollar gap, which is just, um, staggering when you think about it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a three hundred thousand dollar gap, which is just, um, staggering when you think about it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Brian Madgett from New York Life pointed out it's not that they don't want insurance—it's competing with daily expenses, even coffee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Brian Madgett from New York Life pointed out it's not that they don't want insurance-it's competing with daily expenses, even coffee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not an issue of Millennials not wanting to get life insurance; its more a prioritization issue, says Brian Madgett, who leads New York Lifes national life sales and its advanced planning group. The concept of taking care of their families and loved ones is in competition with the big screen tv, car and even that daily cup of coffee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and student loans, saving for kids' education... it all adds up. The survey says they have a seventy-seven percent shortfall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and student loans, saving for kids' education... it all adds up. The survey says they have a seventy-seven percent shortfall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennialsanyone born between 1981 and 1996, so ages 22 to 37 this yearreport a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage, according to the survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Compared to Gen X at forty-five percent and Baby Boomers at thirty-five. It's a generational trend, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Compared to Gen X at forty-five percent and Baby Boomers at thirty-five. It's a generational trend, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By contrast, Gen Xers, born between 1965 and 1980, so 38 to 53 this yearreport a 48% coverage shortfall. Baby Boomers say they have $190,000 of coverage but need $300,000a 37% shortfall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Madgett suggests using holiday family time to talk about it—like when a relative nudges you, like his mom did for him.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Madgett suggests using holiday family time to talk about it-like when a relative nudges you, like his mom did for him.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Madgett suggests using the life insurance gap data as a conversation starter over the holidays. I remember my dad nudging my husband and me to get term life insurance policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he mentioned buying a home or having kids are the big triggers for people to finally get coverage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he mentioned buying a home or having kids are the big triggers for people to finally get coverage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying a home and having kids are the two big things that prompt people to get coverage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And term life is surprisingly affordable—like three hundred bucks a year for a healthy thirty-five-year-old for half a million in coverage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And term life is surprisingly affordable-like three hundred bucks a year for a healthy thirty-five-year-old for half a million in coverage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For a healthy 35-year-old male, it would cost about $250 a year for a 20-year level term policy with a $500,000 death benefit, according to Term4sale.com, where you can run your own numbers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But workplace policies might only cover one or two years of salary, and they disappear if you change jobs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But workplace policies might only cover one or two years of salary, and they disappear if you change jobs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you have life insurance coverage at work, keep in mind that that policy might pay only one- or two-years salary, and it will likely end if you leave your job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Shopping around is key too—premiums vary a lot between companies for the same product.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Shopping around is key too-premiums vary a lot between companies for the same product.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Premiums vary greatly for the same product from different insurers, so shop around.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And checking the insurer's financial strength through ratings agencies, which the Insurance Information Institute can help with.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And checking the insurer's financial strength through ratings agencies, which the Insurance Information Institute can help with.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Insurance Information Institute has links to the ratings agencies and explains why you should check out more than one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's one of those things you know you should do, but it's easy to put off until, uh, life really forces your hand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's one of those things you know you should do, but it's easy to put off until, uh, life really forces your hand.

HostB: Right, and student loans, saving for kids' education... it all adds up. The survey says they have a seventy-seven percent shortfall.
HostA: Compared to Gen X at forty-five percent and Baby Boomers at thirty-five. It's a generational trend, really.
HostB: Madgett suggests using holiday family time to talk about it—like when a relative nudges you, like his mom did for him.
HostA: Yeah, he mentioned buying a home or having kids are the big triggers for people to finally get coverage.
HostB: And term life is surprisingly affordable—like three hundred bucks a year for a healthy thirty-five-year-old for half a million in coverage.
HostA: But workplace policies might only cover one or two years of salary, and they disappear if you change jobs.
HostB: Shopping around is key too—premiums vary a lot between companies for the same product.
HostA: And checking the insurer's financial strength through ratings agencies, which the Insurance Information Institute can help with.
HostB: It's one of those things you know you should do, but it's easy to put off until, uh, life really forces your hand.
